title: government end late payments to firms
story: It is a major victory for hundreds of thousands of small businesses who are crippled by big firms who pay suppliers late.The crackdown comes after The Sun revealed that nine in ten firms who supply government infrastructure projects are paid late.The research, released by the Federation of Small Businesses, follows the collapse of giant government supplier Carillion.Its collapse exposed how mega-firms cripple small businesses with a policy of making them wait 120 days before being paid.And it left small firms out of pocket and the taxpayer a whopping £148million bill.FSB chief Mike Cherry said the Government could free up billions of pounds by overhauling the way contracts are handed out.Current rules lock out cheaper small firms - effectively giving the major construction companies carte blanche to charge whatever they like for public infrastructure projects.Cabinet Office Minister Oliver Dowden last night promised to consider a raft of measures proposed by the FSB that would split up mega contracts and stop huge suppliers who pay late from getting any government work.The organisation said it would free up money for frontline services such as the NHS.Mr Cherry said: “The government wastes billions of pounds when it buys from a handful of large companies.“Today we set out how to save taxpayer money and avoid another Carillion.”Pledging help for small firms crippled with late payments, Mr Dowden said: I welcome these ideas from the FSB. Small businesses are the backbone of the economy and I am determined to level the playing field for them to compete for government contracts.“I will further consider these proposals from the FSB as we move forward with this work. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: government gets kids to run mile
story: The free 15 minute Daily Mile initiative - started in Scotland in 2012 with great success – comes as ministers bid to fulfil a pledge to half the number of obese children by 2030.Campaigners – including The Sun - have branded it a “silver bullet” for boosting health and have pushed for it to be rolled out across the country.Children will be asked to run or jog for 15mins every day in the playground daily come rain, hail or shine.The run does not replace other sports or PE classes and teachers can fit it in during the day whenever they like.A recent study looking at 400 pupils in two Scottish primary schools found the task had improved fitness “remarkably” and made kids leaner.The plan is part of the Government’s obesity strategy to be launched next week to stop us becoming the fattest population in Europe in a decade.Ministers will run a staggering seven public consultations in parallel over 12 weeks this summer on their obesity strategy across advertising, unhealthy BOGOF offers and a potential sugar tax on food like the one slapped on fizzy drinks.The plans could also see restrictions on junk food advertising on television before the 9pm watershed and a potential ban on cartoon characters promoting unhealthy food.Last night Tory MP Dr Sarah Wollaston praised the initiative saying it was a “really positive way of boosting activity, fitness and wellbeing”.Health Secretary Jeremy Hunt has described the Daily Mile as an “excellent initiative” including physical exercise in an “easy, inclusive and fun way”.More than 3,500 schools in 30 plus countries around the globe have taken up the idea since award-winning head teacher Elaine Wylie came up with it six years ago while working at St Ninian’s Primary in Stirling.Researchers compared almost children aged between 4 and 12 at two primary schools in Scotland - one where pupils were doing the Daily Mile, and one where they were not.The children wore accelerometers which recorded how much moderate to vigorous physical activity (MVPA) they were undertaking every day, and how long they were sitting about for.They were measured for body fat and timed on their performance at a shuttle run.Researchers found the kids who were doing the Daily Mile were significantly healthier than those who were not.Schools will be encouraged to take up the practice but it will not be made compulsory.Last night Education Secretary Damian Hinds said: “The Sun are right to champion Initiatives like the Daily Mile which is a great way to encourage young people to get regular physical activity.“The government are investing £320million a year in the Sports Premium to encourage schools to ensure their pupils are active at least once a day.“I know many schools already do this and I’d like to see more and more do so.”TV shows are fuelling obesity by using tubby celebs, a study suggests.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. story: Victoria Atkins said crooks must “understand the consequences of their criminal behaviour” in an interview with The Daily .A trial of the scheme is taking place in an area in North London where at least 14 gangs are fighting turf wars.The Tory MP for Louth &amp Horncastle said: “In the most serious cases, with these people who are exploiting young people, making the lives of local residents a misery, putting fear into people’s hearts when they’re picking children up from the school gates, I think absolutely they should understand the consequences of their criminal behaviour.”The scheme involves social workers, police, NHS staff and counsellors working with young people aged between 10 and 24.As a last resort, the trial can use new powers in the Anti-Social Behaviour, Crime and Policing Act, which allows landlords to kick people out as a result of serious criminal activity.Asked whether she supported the scheme, Ms Atkins said the Government had “changed the law to enable it to happen.”The minister also said she wants to make sure the police have enough powers to deal with gang crime.She added: “If they search someone’s address and they have suspicions this person is at the head of a gang or they’re recruiting young people to a county lines gang, I want the police when they get into the house and they find a zombie knife to have the power to arrest that person on the basis of that, so they’ve got all the tools they need to lock people away.”A poll for the Chartered Institute of Housing found an overwhelming majority of people would be happy to see more social housing built in their area.But the number of affordable homes being built fell to just 5,380 last year as councils feared a backlash over developments.The CIH wants Right to Buy to be suspended to keep the stock of social housing.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: china is firing lasers at us planes as they fly over the pacific us military source claims
story: Twenty suspected attacks have been recorded since September 2017 - and the latest happened in the last two weeks, its reported.A military spokeswoman, who didnt want to be named, told CNN none of the episodes resulted in a medical complaint or injury.But Chinese foreign ministry spokesman Geng Shuang denied the allegations during a regular press briefing on Friday.He said: According to what we have learned from the relevant authorities, the accusations in the relevant reports by US media are totally groundless and purely fabricated.The suspected laser attacks reportedly happened around the East China Sea and signals appeared to come from fishing boats operating in the area and from shore, multiple officials said.Some of the vessels were Chinese-flagged craft, but US officials wouldnt confirm if China were behind all of the incidents, the Wall Street Journal reports.The lasers are said to be smaller, commercial-grade devices, like those pet owners might use to play with their cats.But they still remain dangerous and can temporarily blind pilots or cause eye damage.It comes after military-grade lasers were used against American pilots in Djibouti in East Africa earlier this year.Aircrew suffered minor eye injuries in one case but it prompted the US to launch a formal diplomatic protest with Beijing.Chinese state media denied the claims by US defence officials, and accused them of cooking up phony laser stories.Its thought more such episodes could have occurred but have gone unreported by American pilots.US officials said they considered the latest suspected attacks to be low-level but concerned harassment.The East China Sea has been the subject of a long-running dispute between China and Japan over islands known as the Senkaku chain in Japan and the Diaoyu in China.US military aircraft have regularly conducted freedom of navigation operations over the area to contest an air defence identification zone that Beijing declared in 2013.

title: rat eats cash atm india
story: Bank workers pried open the broken machine to find the money ripped to shreds — and a dead rodent.The rat had dodged CCTV cameras and burrowed into the ATM for its expensive last meal in Tinsukia, India.Workers had just filled up the machine with new notes the day before it stopped working.State Bank of India manager Chandan Sharma said: The ATM was out of order for a few days and when our technicians opened the kiosk we were shocked to find shredded notes and a dead rat.Mr Sharma added: We have started an investigation into this rare incident and will take measures to prevent a recurrence.SBI is Indias largest bank with more than 50,000 ATMs spread across the country.Most ATMs in India have security cameras installed.But an inspection of the camera footage at the ATM in Tinsukia showed no rat entering it.Of the 2.9 million rupees (£32,000) in the ATM, 1.7 million rupees (£19,000) were recovered intact.But banknotes worth 1.2 million rupees (£13,400) were destroyed.Police Supt Mugdhajyoti Mahanta said: When the engineer and other officials opened the ATM, they found destroyed notes and also found a dead rat inside the ATM.

title: tusk of woolly mammoth dug up in staffordshire
story: The incredible discovery was made by a worker with the edge of his bucket at the Whitemoor Haye mine near Alrewas.Only last month a mammoths leg bone was also unearthed at the same Tarmac-operated site.Britain’s last known woolly mammoths died after they fell into holes left by melting ice blocks - and the last colossal creatures are believed to have walked Britain 14,000 years ago.The tusk, found buried deep in gravel, will now be displayed in an Ice Age exhibition at The Hive library in Worcester, reports the Express and Star.A member of the Worcestershire Archive and Archaeology Service team wrote about the discovery on social media.They posted: “The feeling when you find more bits of woolly mammoth two days before the launch of your major new Ice Age exhibition.Rob Hedge, who worked to bring the remains to the Ice Age exhibition at the library, said the find was really exciting.He said: “The discovery is close to where last month we found a woolly mammoth radius, which is the leg bone.“The tusk is very fragmented. It was found quite deep in the gravel. One of the quarry workers found the tusk with the edge of his bucket.“We had to clean around it and photograph it. It then got packed with water into bags and came back to the office.“Then it got dried out very slowly – if you do it too quick it can cause it to fall apart.Some believe that mammoths, which roamed the Earth around 10,000 years ago, were wiped out by an asteroid which sparked huge climate change.Other theories suggest humans love for hunting is to blame.Britains last known woolly mammoths died about 14,000 years ago after falling into a hole left by melting blocks of ice.Experts were last year shocked to find fossilised remains of five healthy mammoths in a Shropshire gravel pit in 1986 – partly because they believed the species had been wiped out in Britain much earlier.The discovery of five mammoths’ remains in one place suggested something unusual had killed them.Scientists from the Natural History Museum believe this unusual event was a ‘kettle hole’ that the mammoths fell into.The hole is thought to have resulted from the melting of a mass of ice trapped in glacial deposits.It is really exciting. We have had more complete tusks from this region but what is interesting about this one, even though it is in bits, we are able to see the structure of the tusk and it is quite small.“This is likely to be in the later period of the mammoth.”It is one of many finds made across the West Midlands recently – with another set of bones discovered along the River Tame in Staffordshire last month.The bone found was believed to have been the elbow or lower front leg bone of a woolly mammoth.

title: mum spent 4k travelling to aussie wedding only to be told her baby wasnt welcome
story: The wedding guest was due to travel thousands of miles to Australia for her cousins big day but was hit with the bad news after shelling out for her flight.She told Netmums she had known about the wedding for a year but wasnt told at any point her baby wouldnt be allowed at the ceremony.It was only when she received an official invitation three weeks before she was due to fly that she discovered bringing the tot would cause a problem.She said: My cousin invited us to his wedding in Australia with 12 months notice.Sent us an email with the date no further info. My daughter is five months old. So my family said we would attend and we bought the flights.She added: I chased for the actual invitation about 100 times and eventually it arrived three weeks before we flew.The invite said no children. I flagged that they really should have mentioned this before I bought the flight.When she touched down in Australia, the mum was told by her unimpressed family she would have to find a babysitter for her child after she decided to bring her along.The mum said: Am I being unreasonable to think its a joke they cant make an exception for a breastfeed baby flying from England?Dont have kids at your wedding, no problem. Dont make me spend £4k on flights and accommodation to be told that my baby cant come.Other mums were quick to support her and said they would be furious if put in a similar position.One said: OMG thats ridiculous! Youre flying to the other side of the world... I personally wouldnt let strangers look after my child.Id be fuming too! I totally get the no child thing, I really do, but this is definitely an exception.Another added: Id be furious. If couples dont want children at their wedding thats absolutely their prerogative but they need to make it clear in plenty of time for guest to make arrangements for childcare or decide not to go.Failing to mention this minor detail until you were committed to going is extremely thoughtless.

title: uk weather spanish plume heatwave sunshine 33 degrees c
story: Temperatures are set to soar as high as 33C at the beginning of next week — making Britain hotter than Benidorm.The sun was beating down as the 50th anniversary of the Isle of Wight music festival continued today.Festivalgoers listened to the likes of Rita Ora, Nile Rodgers and Kasabian in glorious sunshine as the mercury soared.Average temperatures for this time of year usually hover around 21C in London, 18C in Manchester and 17C in Scotland.But after a Midsummer’s Day scorcher of 24C tomorrow the Met Office forecasts 27C by Tuesday and temperatures then hitting the thirties.The scorching heatwave will peak next Wednesday on what forecasters believe could be the hottest day of 2018.But forecasters now expect widespread sunshine with temperatures rising 4C each day until the middle of next week.Bookmakers Coral cut odds to 2/1 on highs beating June’s UK record temperature of 35.6C, set on June 29, 1957, at Camden Square, London, and June 28, 1976, in Southampton.The Met Office said Northern Ireland could break its 30.8C all-time temperature record, set on June 30, 1976, at Knockarevan, Co Fermanagh, and July 12, 1983, at Shaws Bridge, Belfast.Sunday will see highs of 25C in the South East and London, but temperatures will be well above average widely. Met Office forecaster Alex Burkill said: “It will be hot and sunny everywhere in the UK by Tuesday, with high pressure.“Tuesday looks like 27C, and Wednesday and Thursday could nudge into the 30s in Scotland.“It will be hot right up to the North of the UK, with a chance Northern Ireland could beat its all-time maximum temperature record of 30.8C.”The Weather Outlook forecaster Brian Gaze said: “Its a marvellous Midsummers Day for most of Britain.“Computer models show 35C isnt out of the question in England’s South from midweek as temperatures continue to rise amid a Spanish plume of warm air.”Coral spokesman Harry Aitkenhead said: “Punters reckon records will tumble as June melts.”If Britain does hit 30C it will be as hot as Gibraltar and parts of southern Spain, such as Marbella, which are also forecast to be around 30C.Temperatures soared to a scorching 29.1C (84F) in St Jamess Park in title: hms queen elizabeth ii aircraft carrier returns portsmouth
story: HMS Queen Elizabeth is the largest aircraft carrier ever commissioned by the Navy and weighs in at a whopping 65,000 tons.The jewel of the Royal Navy sailed into the Hampshire port at around 9am this morning, after another trial at sea.Incredible images show the massive ship dwarfing tugboats that were helping it manoeuvre into port.She has returned from her latest series of work-ups and trials, so crew can get used to the ship and stretch their sea legs.The £3.1billion super ship was first launched in December and was named after a super-dreadnought from the First World War.Britains armed forces are massively bolstered by the massive threat posed to any enemies by the colossal aircraft carrier - which can carry up to 60 planes.It is staffed by around 650 crew and can travel more than half way around the world before needing to be refuelled.Her sister ship is named HMS Prince of Wales, and is the eighth to bear that name.In August 2017, the colossal vessel was pictured during her sea trials off the coast of Scotland, alongside USS Donald Cook, USS Philippine Sea and the colossal American carrier USS George HW Bush.Experts reckon the ship is expected to remain in Portsmouth for resupply for a couple of weeks, until being deployed to the US later this summer.HMS Queen Elizabeth set sail from the Rosyth dockyard in Fife on June 26.The 65,000-tonne carrier passed under the iconic Forth Road Bridge, then spending several weeks in the North Sea for sea trials.She arrived in Portsmouth Harbour on August 16, 2017, sharing the message home on social media as it came into the naval base.Captain Jerry Kyd said he felt a huge amount of pride ahead of the vessel berthing in her home port.On November 22, 2017, HMS Queen Elizabeth returned from the second period of sea trials.The giant ship made port in Portsmouth on June 23, 2018 after the latest Helicopter Sea Trials.The Royal Navy’s new aircraft carrier had a leak so serious it may need to go back into dry dock at Rosyth — for repairs that will cost millions.A faulty seal around one of the vast warship’s propeller shafts meant 200 litres of sea water poured in every hour.Sources said at the time there was a “significant” defect with the stern seal, an inflatable rubber ring that fits around one of the propeller shafts.The problem was spotted during sea trials.It reportedly had the fault when it was delivered by ship building partnership the ­Aircraft Carrier Alliance, which could mean they will have to pay for the repairs, not the Ministry of Defence.The aircraft carrier spent six weeks in the North Sea for sea trials.During the trip, the aircraft undertook handling and speed tests off the east coast of Scotland.The Queen officially welcomed the UK’s new £3.1billion aircraft carrier into the Royal Navy fleet and declared it the “best of British”.Her Maj arrived on board HMS Queen Elizabeth in an elegant purple outfit, at Portsmouth Naval base on December 7.She underwent sea trials with Chinook and Merlin helicopters in March 2018.The two helicopter type trials were carried out in tandem, ensuring the time available on deck was used to maximum effect and avoiding a second voyage out to sea later in the year.It is due to head to America’s east coast for F-35 flight trials which will begin in October 2018.The HMS Queen Elizabeth will be declared as having a full operational capability in 2020.During her estimated 50-year working life, HMS Queen Elizabeth could be pressed into action for various work such as high-intensity war fighting or providing humanitarian aid and disaster relief anywhere in the world.Each aircraft carrier will provide the armed forces with a four-acre military operating base, which can be deployed worldwide.When the ship has its full complement of 36 F-35B fighters and four helicopters on board the crew will increase to about 1,600.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: nfl cheerleader angelina rosa labelled skinny fat
story: Angelina Rosa is suing the football team for unfair treatment after being “body-shamed” and “belittled” by the Houston Texans squad leader.The dancer says the female coach routinely threatened to cut her from the team for “not being toned despite being thin”.Speaking at a press conference in New York on Friday, Angelina said: “On numerous occasions I was belittled and body shamed. I was described and called out with the term ‘skinny fat’.”She then told how before a game last year, her coach held her back as the rest of the cheerleaders ran out onto the field.Angelina explained: “She (her coach) then stated, ‘Angelina, you are about to be cut for a lifetime.’ I had no clue what she was referring to as I had worked very hard on my appearance.“She then walked me over to a corner of the locker room with herself and several other alumni helpers.“Before I knew it Texans logo duct tape was found, I heard ‘this will hurt a bit’, as I watched my skin being pulled, stretched, and taped tightly on myself.”Rosa says she starved herself and survived on just popcorn and water to stay skinny.But shortly after the duct tape humiliation, she quit the squad and joined a lawsuit that was filed earlier this month by five of her former colleagues.The cheerleaders say they were paid just $7.25 (£5.40) per hour and were not given food allowances during trips.They also alleged a culture of sexual harassment, impropriety and one where they were constantly reminded that they were replaceable.At the press conference, Angelina’s attorney, Gloria Allred, held up photographs of her client in her uniform and said: “It’s ridiculous to call a person who looks like this ‘skinny-fat’.“First of all, no one should be called fat, let alone ‘skinny-fat’.”The other cheerleaders who have taken action against the organization are Hannah Turnbow, Ainsley Parish, Morgan Wiederhold, Ashley Rodriguez, and Kelly Neuner.Earlier this month, a former Dallas Cowboys cheerleader launched her own suit against that team.She complained that its mascot earned more than she did and is now demanding back-pay.

title: queen royal ascot boozy punters pimms
story: Her Maj, 92, was wheeled down the course in a horse-drawn carriage in front of thousands of racegoers on the final day of the festival.Pimms flowed in the stands as the Queen, joined by the Duke of York, waved to the crowds — who brandished their mobile phones to record the procession.Wearing an aquamarine outfit with pearls and a feathered hat, she was carted down the final furlong before the start of racing.The Queen attended the Berkshire course for every day of Royal Ascot this year amid scorching sunshine and temperatures in the high twenties.Stacks of empty Pimms jugs lined the pavilions as suited-and-booted revellers quaffed drinks to stave off the heat.Celebs were out in force to soak up the fun and pose in their posh clobber.Kelly Brook wore a £995 Roksanda bow sleeve crepe dress — and Dame Helen Mirren looked glam in a tie-neck belted floral midi.Earlier in the week Meghan Markle made her Ascot debut — while yesterday Fergie and Michael Owen were among the famous faces taking in the action.On Friday Her Majesty presented the coveted Gold Cup to veteran jockey Frankie Dettori, who was at his racing best on the 7-4 joint favourite Stradivarius.It was the 47-year-old sixth Gold Cup win and he treated the 70,000 crowd to a trademark flying dismount.

title: ethiopia prime minster rally explosion abiy ahmed
story: The blast, believed to have been caused by a grenade, may have been an attempt to assassinate reformist leader Abiy Ahmed, according to reports.Dramatic footage captures Ahmed being rushed from the scene in Ethiopian capitals Meskel Square as thousands of people panic in horror.The 41-year-old, who became prime minister in April, says “a few people” are dead.Dozens of others have been seriously hurt.People on social media reported buildings and ambulances had caught fire after the explosion.Others said shots had been fired.Mr Ahmed, who has three children, said: Today was a day for unity, and the day love was raining, although forces who dont want to see this amazing day have tried to stop this.There are a few death, and wounded during this attack.This action will not derail the peace that is ongoing in Ethiopia right now.He sent condolences to families of those who were killed.The politician is the countrys first leader from the ethnic Oromo group, which has been at the centre of nearly three years of anti-government protests.However, todays demonstration was organised in support of the dad to three.Authorities are still investigating the blast.

title: at least 100000 attend march calling for vote on final brexit deal
story: Some attendees chanted "where's Jeremy Corbyn?" during the march. The Labour leader is opposed to another referendum on EU membership.Mr Corbyn was visiting a refugee camp in Jordan on Saturday. A Sky News journalist accompanying him on the trip asked him to comment on camera about the march, but he declined.A counter-protest has been held in Westminster by hundreds of those in favour of leaving the European Union.After the anti-Brexit rally, Labour MP David Lammy tweeted: "We will not give up. We will fight for our right for a People's Vote. It is the people who will bear the brunt of Brexit & it is the people who should decide Britain's future." Businesswoman and campaigner Gina Miller also addressed the march, telling people: "Let us hear you shout for a people's vote".The march saw politicians, citizens and campaigners from across the UK walk from Pall Mall to Parliament Square, calling on the government to listen to their voices and give them a say.Among those taking part were farmers, doctors, teachers, delivery drivers, students, fishermen and veterans from the Armed Forces - as well as former supporters of Brexit.One marcher told Sky News: "It's two years on now. Things have changed. Europe has changed. We should have another say."Another accused the government of being incompetent.They said: "When the vote took place, we could not have anticipated how incompetent this government would be on negotiating."It's not good enough to say 'the people said this at one point'&#8230"Matthew Mann, originally from south Gloucestershire, who moved to the Netherlands in 2016 for work, said: "I'm here to show what a European looks like."I'm married to a French wife, I have two children who are dual national, and we live in Holland and are caught up in this administrative mess."I have lived and worked across Europe, it's home." There was a cross-party presence at the march, with members of the Conservatives, Labour, Greens and Lib Dems all calling on the government to allow a vote on the final deal that is reached with the EU.

title: brexit and business is the government listening
story: No deal must be avoided, as its Brexit position paper-come-"risk assessment" says in as many words.None of this will be any surprise to Number 10, which has been talking to businesses at length, even while those businesses have been complaining they're not being being listened too.A survey in February showed 94% of more than 600 smaller firms thought their concerns were falling on deaf ears, while Airbus' Broughton union convener, representing 6,500 North Wales workers, said he has been to Downing Street twice and thinks no one is listening.It knows Airbus is serious, it knows the number one concern of importing and exporting firms of all sizes is uncertainty, but it has to deliver Brexit and it has to negotiate the best deal it can with an EU council protecting its own interests.Airbus may have waited until now to issue its warning of severe disruption because it didn't want to be seen as part of Project Fear.

title: final campaign push ahead of historic election in turkey
story: Polls suggest it is unlikely Mr Ince will win the presidency, but he could run close enough to force a second round on 8 July.Turkey faces a series of domestic and foreign problems: the Turkish lira has lost around a fifth of its value against the dollar in just a year, inflation has reached double digits, Turkish forces are engaged in action in Syria and Iraq, and there is an ongoing civil war with the Kurdish population in the south east of the country.In another challenge to President Erdogan, an unlikely coalition of opposition parties have teamed together to break the parliamentary majority enjoyed by his AKP party.The three parties, made up of secularists, nationalists and Islamists, make unlikely bedfellows, but have come together in an attempt to break Mr Erdogan's sixteen-year grip on power.If they do succeed in the parliamentary elections but Mr Erdogan is re-elected, Turkey could face months of political stalemate as each side tries to thwart the other. Turkey has lived under a state of emergency since an attempted coup in 2016."Erdogan became like a dictator in this country" an opposition activist told Sky."We have a lack of democracy, we have lack of justice, no education, nothing at all, so stealing is the big problem in this country."So even people supporting AKP - Mr Erdogan - are saying enough is enough. It's been sixteen years!"

title: game of thrones stars kit harington and rose leslie marry at family castle
story: The actors met in 2012 while filming the long-running saga in Iceland, where they were playing Jon Snow and Ygritte. Their engagement was announced in The Times last year, and a wedding date of 23 June was posted at the Huntly registration office in Scotland.The actress - whose full name is Rose Eleanor Arbuthnot-Leslie - is a descendant of Charles II and her family owns the 12th-century Wardhill Castle in Aberdeenshire, where the ceremony took place. Her father said he was "thrilled" for his daughter as she prepared to marry her former co-star.Guests lined the path as the couple left the church after the ceremony and showered them with flower petal confetti.They got into an old land Rover Destroyer decorated with "Just Married" paper hearts and tin cans tied to the back. Speaking outside the castle before the ceremony, Sebastian Leslie said: "We are absolutely thrilled for Kit and Rose to be marrying today."Co-stars Emilia Clarke, who played Daenerys Targaryen, and Peter Dinklage, who played Tyrion Lannister, were seen arriving in nearby Aberdeen on Friday.Fans of the Sky Atlantic series had been gathering outside the castle hoping to catch a glimpse of the stars.Two Chinese students, who are currently studying in Glasgow, brought flowers.Yunyao Li, 23, and Qiong dan Xu, 23, said they were fans of Jon Snow."We would like to see him if possible," one said.The impressive castle where the wedding was held, complete with turrets and surrounded by countryside and woodland, can sleep 16 people in the main house but there are more properties in the grounds. The castle's website says: "This venue is ideal for those wanting to plan their own day without having to use a set format."And it adds: "The castle offers a superb backdrop for a marquee wedding on the lawn for your big day complete with floodlights to illuminate the castle whilst watching fireworks from the terrace!"In an interview with Italian Men's Vogue, Harington, who was born in west London to a playwright and a baronet, said it was easy to fall in love with Leslie. Speaking of their time together on the show, he said: "If you're already attracted to someone, and then they play your love interest in the show, it becomes very easy to fall in love."

title: miss great britain to keep swimsuit category
story: The 2017 #MeToo campaign against sexual harassment which started in Hollywood has led to a greater scrutiny of the objectification of women across the globe.Earlier this year, F1 racing decided it would no longer use promotion women, known as grid girls. Similarly, the British Professional Darts Corporation stopped using "walk-on-girls" as player escorts.But the decision by Miss Great Britain to keep its round has been welcomed by some in the pageant industry.Poppy Haskell is Miss Swimsuit UK. She says winning the contest, which involved her wearing a bikini in front of judges, has kick-started her career in modelling and promotions work."Women know exactly what they are going into," Miss Haskell told Sky News.Body image expert Natashe Devon told Sky News that where it can become a problem if these image promote one body-type as the ideal."If you are bombarded by unrealistic imagery of people who look unattainable, then it's going start to negatively affect your self-esteem," Ms Devon said."But if your body diverges from what we consider to be beautiful, if for example we have scars, or blemishes or stretch marks, you are representing something that is a little bit different, then it's been shown to have a positive impact on how people feel about themselves."That is what led one woman to create the a plus-size beauty pageant.Samantha Coote founded Miss British Beauty Curve, a pageant for women size 14 or over, after she felt unable to enter a traditional pageant because she was plus-size. Ms Coote says her contest does have a swimwear round, and for plus-size ladies it's liberating."It's a great round, it's fun!" Ms Coote told Sky News.

title: saudi arabia poised to lift ban on women drivers
story: We joined women practising their driving skills on a simulator.One told us: "I can go to work, I can go to the hospital, I can take my children to school. My life is better. It's changed my life."Another said: "I'm so excited. I can't wait to get my licence."Until now women have had to rely on a male relative or  to take them to places. Driving was illegal because women were deemed too incompetent and the government view was that driving would give them too much independence.But global human rights groups say the lifting of the ban comes at a time when there is an unprecedented crackdown on political dissent.Some of the women who have campaigned for decades to lift the ban have been arrested in recent weeks.Of 17 women detained, nine are still in jail. Government-aligned local media have described them as "traitors", accusing them of colluding with hostile foreign governments.

title: swimsuit model contests empower women they must not be scrapped
story: When I was growing up it was never my intention to be a model. I studied journalism at university but I soon realised an office job was not my calling.My move into the modelling industry came out of the blue.I was 18 years old and performing in a ballet show when someone from an agency spotted me. It led to some part-time modelling work but I have to admit I wasn't making a lot of money.I first heard about Miss Swimsuit UK through a close friend who had entered in 2015.It opened up a lot of opportunities for her so, in 2017, I decided to take the plunge and give the competition a go.My fellow contestants were from all sorts of backgrounds and there were plenty of different personalities.One woman worked in the navy, another worked in the pharmaceutical industry. Some women were shy, others were more confident.I took part in catwalks, wearing different swimsuits and answered questions from a presenter to give an impression of my personality.For me, the competition was a way of showcasing my gym work and healthy eating. The whole event was a celebration of the female form and for all the contestants, the event was about empowering each other.I didn't feel I was being judged in a negative way. I found it very liberating being in a swimsuit and people had worked hard to be able to enter the competition.To be named the winner was incredible. It was a massive boost to my confidence and it turned out to be the catalyst for my modelling career, which went into overdrive.I'm now modelling all over the world and hoping to move into TV presenting and producing.My parents - who both have corporate jobs - are immensely proud of me and my boyfriend has always been extremely supportive.   You have to set boundaries and I said to him from the start: "This is my passion - take it or leave it."I feel like I've finally found my niche in the industry. Having curves is great for swimsuit modelling.I'm not skinny and tall like a fashion model and I would never work as a glamour model because I wouldn't ever pose naked.Unfortunately though I've had a few bad experiences in the industry.There have been instances where male photographers have tried push me further than I wanted to go. It's definitely an issue in the industry.

title: uk enjoys heatwave with 30c forecast next week
story: On the south coast, Margate's beach was a popular spot, with people cooling off in the sea pools.High pressure has brought settled and clear weather, with temperatures reaching the mid 20s in the South on Saturday.The warm weather will continue over the weekend, though the Shetland Islands may get some rain on Sunday morning.By Wednesday, forecasters are predicting that temperatures could hit 30C (86F). Chief meteorologist Frank Saunders said: "As warmer air from the continent moves towards the UK from Wednesday, temperatures will climb into the mid to high 20s quite widely, even in parts of Scotland and Northern Ireland."By this stage, some places in England and Wales will very likely top 30C - it's not unlikely somewhere could reach 32C (90F)."With almost wall-to-wall sunshine we'll certainly be looking at conditions which many of us would call a heatwave." The Met Office estimates the weather will last until the end of June and could even continue into the first few days of July. UV and pollen levels will also be very high.Owen Landeg, from Public Health England, said: "For some people, such as older people, those with underlying health conditions and those with young children, the summer heat can bring real health risks.Temperatures across the rest of Europe are also steadily increasing, with Barcelona enjoying 27C (81F), Rome 28C (82F) and Lisbon basking in 26C (79F).World Cup fans will be enjoying temperatures of 29C (84F) in Moscow today.The highest temperature on record in the UK this year is 29.1C, which was recorded in St James's Park on 19 April. The highest June temperature ever recorded in the UK is 35.6C (96F) at Camden Square on 29 June 1957 and Southampton on 28 June 1976.Heatwave alerts will be sent out by Public Health England once daytime temperatures reach 30C (86F) and nighttime temperatures reach 15C (59F). Part of the advice will be preventing children taking part in "vigorous outdoor play".

title: mps slam theresa delaying cap
story: NewsMPs slam Theresa May for delaying cap on fixed odds betting machinesThe Government last month agreed to the cap on the units, dubbed the crack-cocaine of gambling&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByKeir Mudie19:34, 23 JUN 2018Updated19:38, 23 JUN 2018NewsCap on betting machines has been put off (Image: PA)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet politics updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email Angry MPs have urged Theresa May to rethink the “immoral and dangerous” delay on bringing in a &pound2 stake limit for fixed odds betting terminals.  The Government last month agreed to the cap on the units, dubbed the crack-cocaine of gambling. But Ministers delayed the new rules to 2020 under pressure from the gambling sector, which said it needs time to prepare. A cross-party group including Labour’s Carolyn Harris, Tory Iain Duncan Smith and the SNP’s Ronnie Cowan has now written to the Prime Minister demanding the limit be in place next year. Mrs Harris said: “We fought long and hard and the Government came to the right decision. “To allow the Chancellor to delay this is immoral and dangerous.

title: 11 best spots uk watch
story: Advertorial11 best spots in the UK to watch an amazing sunset this summerThis week marks the summer solstice – and is also the official start of summer. So what better time to explore the UK and take in some of the country’s most breathtaking bike rides?&nbspShareByHolly Thatcher14:24, 22 JUN 2018Updated14:41, 22 JUN 2018Advertorial (Image: Getty)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailWe've been blessed with some decent weather already in 2018 - but this week is when summer *officially* begins. June 21, the summer solstice in the Northern Hemisphere, is the longest day in the year - affording us approximately 17 hours of daylight. Technically, this also means that the nights will start drawing in again now - so there's really no time like the present to get out and explore the great outdoors on some of the country’s most breathtaking bike rides. We've taken a look around the UK to find the best places to watch the sun setting.  1. Museum of Scottish Lighthouses, Fraserburgh, Scotland   A small village called Maud in Aberdeenshire offers a starting place for a traffic-free cycle to the coast. If you're in the mood to learn then head to the Museum of Scottish Lighthouses in Fraserburgh. The sun will set at around 10.12pm this week in this part of Scotland, so you've got loads of time to enjoy the start of the summer.  Bike need replacing?       If your existing bike needs replacing, you'll want something efficient and speedy for the roads - like the Carrera Parva Hybrid bike , which comes in versions for both men and women and is now just &pound210 (a saving of &pound90).  And if you don't need a new bike, why not have yours checked over before setting off. Like any mode of transport your bike needs to be looked after and regularly checked for wear and tear.  Halfords offers a 32-point Free Bike Check which includes:   Frame, saddle and handlebar Wheels including tyres, rims, spokes and hubs Brake system including levers, calipers, pads and cables / hoses Drivetrain including gears, levers, chain, bottom bracket, cranks and cables   2. The Eden Project, Cornwall      Why not spend the day enjoying the amazing sights at the Eden Project? Best of all, if you arrive by bike you'll get a discount on entry. The sun sets on Eden at around 9:30pm on the solstice. Bear in mind though that the Eden Project shuts at 6pm, so you'll need to watch the sun go down somewhere nearby.   Get there in style on the Carrera Subway 1 Hybrid Bike , &pound300. With easy to use 24 speed Shimano gearing, your effort for building speed will be minimised on all terrains, while its lightweight aluminium frame means you can quickly and efficiently ride to your destination.   Camping out?      Planning to camp? Be sure you book in advance as you won't want to be without a pitch.  Croft Farm Holiday Park is just a mile from the Eden Project and three miles from the beach. Pentewan Sands is also nearby and boasts amazing family facilities - as well as the nearby Pentewan Cycle Trail.   Consider taking a Halfords Vis A Vis 4 Person Tent with you, which is currently reduced to just &pound60, (was &pound150, save &pound90). The simple tunnel design is easy to pitch in approximately 20 minutes. With two separate bedrooms and a living area, it's perfect for families or groups of friends.   For additional comfort pack an Urban Escape Folding Table And Bench Set , &pound40 (was &pound50, save &pound10) which folds down into a single carry case to make it easy to transport and store.      3. Pembrokeshire Coast National Park, Wales   The Pembrokeshire Coast Path is an absolutely beautiful part of Wales and a stunning place to watch the sun go down. There are loads of campsites in the area, including some unique places to stay. There are plenty of bike routes too, with some offering traffic-free options if you want a more peaceful ride. In Pembrokeshire you can expect the sun to set around 9:39pm.  Why not try..       The Boardman ADV 8.8 Adventure Bike , &pound750, is a bike truly made to help you explore new possibilities. This bike is adept at riding in comfort on roads but really excels when you want to get off the beaten track.         4. White Nancy, Cheshire      Located on Kerridge Hill, White Nancy is a local landmark from which you can see all around the area, from Wales to the west and the Pennines to the north. From time to time White Nancy is painted to look like other things, like a Christmas pudding or with Olympic rings when London hosted in 2012. The sun will set over White Nancy at around 9:36 this week.  Need to drive?     Heading further afield to enjoy the sunny days? If you're packing up the whole family into the car for a camping trip, make sure it's in good running order first.  A Free Car Check performed by Halfords experts will put your mind at rest. Book online or just pop in to your local Halfords store and trained colleagues will carry out a free car bulb check and check your battery, wiper blades, engine oil level and air conditioning, and check for any windscreen chips. They'll even give you a free screenwash top-up too.    If you're making an unfamiliar journey, don't forget to get the Garmin Drive Sat Nav , &pound79.99 (was &pound99.99, save &pound20.99). With lifetime map updates you're never going to find yourself driving down a newly-closed street or down a disused road.   5. Edinburgh Castle, Scotland   There are few places that are as stunning as Edinburgh Castle, located atop Castle Rock. The views of Edinburgh from the castle are amazing, and a great place to watch the end of the day roll around. Sunset here will take place at 9:58pm.  6. Hampstead Heath, London   The scenery on Hampstead Heath always pleases the eye. This amazing part of London has views of every landmark you could hope for and it's a wonderful place to watch the sun go down. This will happen at around 9:18pm in the capital.        7. Osborne House, Isle of Wight      The home of Queen Victoria and Prince Albert is quite a sight to see. Accessible by bike (and ferry, if you're not an island resident), it's the ideal place to see during the day before you settle down somewhere to watch the sunset. If you're up for the cycle, Shanklin Chine on the west of the island is well worth an evening visit.   Do it with ease - and classic style - on the Pendleton Somerby Electric Hybrid Bike , &pound750. With added electrically powered pedal assistance, it delivers 40 - 50 miles of range through a rear hub motor with speed sensor. This extra power is enough to guarantee effortless rides, taking the strain out of hills and making moving off from a standstill much easier.   If you prefer, this bike is also available in a non electric version and in a range of colours - we love the mint green !  The sunset starts at 9:18pm near Osborne House and 9:17pm in Shanklin Chine.     8. Ness Point, Lowestoft          Ness Point is the UK's most easterly point. This makes it a great place to ride to on National Cycle Route 1. Make yourself comfortable on the Halfords XL Waterproof Picnic Blanket , &pound10 (half price) and watch the waves crash in as the sun goes down.  Sunset is 9:16 at the UK's most easterly point.     9. Blackpool Pleasure Beach, Lancashire      With plenty of places to cycle in the area you could have an amazing day out in Blackpool. Start with a ride to the Pleasure Beach, and have some fun with the kids (or without them!) on the roller coasters. When all that's done you can have fish and chips while the sun sets on another day. The sun will go set at around 9:43 in Blackpool.     10. Cotswolds, England   Spread over six counties there's a lot to see in the Cotswolds. Consider taking a ride through the picturesque Castle Combe to take in the amazing houses and the stunning market square. The sun sets on this beautiful village at 9:26pm     Find your way by car - and beat the traffic       If you're driving to somewhere new then why not add a sat nav to your car? The TomTom GO 6200 , &pound270, (was &pound339.99, save &pound69.99) adds real-time traffic information to the navigational benefits of a sat nav (smartphone required for this feature).         11. Giant's Causeway, Northern Ireland

title: baby hailed miracle stick dynamite
story: NewsBaby hailed "miracle stick of dynamite" after being born when her mum was clinically infertile due to chemotherapyNel Williams' mum, Kate, was being treated by cancer beating drugs that should have affected her fertility - but she managed to carry the healthy baby to full term&nbspShareByAnna Slater10:52, 23 JUN 2018Updated14:17, 23 JUN 2018NewsNel as a baby, with her delighted mum Kate (Image: WalesOnline/ WS)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA little girl has been hailed a miracle stick of dynamite after she was born when her mum was clinically infertile due to chemotherapy treatment. Nel Williams is now a thriving ten-year-old who loves playing the piano, watching football and performing on stage - but while her mum was pregnant, her life hung in the balance.  Kate was diagnosed with an aggressive form of breast cancer in 2005 after spotting a large lump after her armpit, but after a lumpectomy and a mastectomy, she was told it had spread.   Her only option was intensive chemotherapy, which severely affects fertility, Wales Online reports.   But despite being under the cosh of cancer-beating drug herceptin Kate discovered she was expecting her third child – one of just a handful in the world known to have conceived during such arduous treatment.   “It was all absolutely terrifying,” said Kate, 47, who lives in Penarth, Wales. “We went for a scan at four weeks and in the middle of this big, black abyss we were staring at this bright, beating light which was her heart. “My husband, Huw, said at the time that she ‘deserved a cuddle’ so we made the decision to stop my chemotherapy. “We didn’t know what the condition would be of the foetus or whether she’d be disabled when she was born but she’d survived this far so we wanted to give her a chance.” Kate said she knew she was taking a huge gamble by coming off herceptin during pregnancy but her oncologist assured her she was in good physical shape and responding well to treatment.  “It was quite an agonising decision because I was running the risk of my two other children losing their mum,” she said. “But the staff at Velindre Cancer Centre, as well as my midwife who’d been there for the delivery of my two other children, were fantastic.” Daughter Nel was born at their former home in Pontcanna, Cardiff, on Tuesday, October 23, weighing a very healthy 8lbs 9oz. “They monitored her throughout the pregnancy and she was growing fine,” Kate added. “The only thing she had ‘wrong’ with her was having just one kidney but that’s not an irregular occurrence.” Nel, a pupil at Albert Primary School in Penarth, has now decided to shave off all her hair for Velindre Cancer Centre in honour of her mum and nan Susie Beer who has stage four breast cancer.

title: conman posed doctor dating website
story: NewsConman posed as doctor on dating website for widows to swindle lonely pensioner's life savingsAkinyemi Adigun convinced a woman in her 70s to give him almost £10,000 which he promised to pay back - but never did&nbspShareByArun LalPaul BeardDanya Bazaraa16:08, 23 JUN 2018NewsAkinyemi Adigun is now facing jail (Image: Paul Beard / SWNS)&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA conman posed as a doctor on a dating website for widows to swindle thousands of pounds from a lonely pensioner.  Akinyemi Adigun, 35, convinced a woman in her 70s to give him almost &pound10,000 which he promised to pay back. But Adigun, of Moston, Manchester, never repaid the money and stopped contacting the victim after he had drained her life savings. Now Adigun is facing jail after he was found guilty on Friday by a unanimous verdict of possessing criminal property following a trial at Warwick Crown Court.  He had told the victim, who had lost her husband three years earlier, he was called Dr Marcus Harry and was a British medic working in Nepal.  Prosecutor Daniel Wright told the court the victim, from Leamington Spa, Warwickshire, fell for Adigun after joining a dating website for widows in September 2015. He said: She found herself getting lonely and, at the suggestion of a friend, she joined a dating site for widows. She was contacted by 'Dr Marcus Harry,' who said he was a 50-year-old male from Bristol who was working overseas in Nepal. They hit it off, and within a month Dr Marcus Harry starts to ask for money from her. At first these were small amounts. It began with a request over WhatsApp, asking her if she would mind getting him &pound50 of iTunes vouchers which he said he was unable to get hold of in Nepal. She agreed, and bought a &pound50 voucher at Argos in Leamington before photographing it and sending the picture to him by email. Two weeks later Dr Harry told her he was planning to fly back to the UK on October 17, but was unable to get hold of the &pound1,000 he needed for the flight - so she agreed to send it to him on the basis that he would repay it on his return.

title: football superfans memoirs crushing defeat
story: NewsFootball superfan's memoirs of crushing defeat made into new film The Bromley Boys starring Alan DaviesDave Roberts' experiences of dedication and despair with his team Bromley FC has made it onto the big screen&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByAntonia Paget19:44, 23 JUN 2018News&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt was 1966 and the nation was riding high on football fever.  For many youngsters Bobby Moore and his team’s triumph marked a high point in their love affair with the beautiful game.  One of them was Dave Roberts. But there is something that makes his story of dedication to a team a bit different.  Now it has been made into a film &shystarring comic Alan Davies and Martine McCutcheon – plus young Game of Thrones &shyactor Brenock O’Connor.  Every fan knows the occasional pain of crushing disappointment. But week after week, Dave experienced little else. In the late 60s his team Bromley FC were in such a state that Dave would turn up to every game with his football boots, in case they were a player short. They conceded so many goals the &shyopposition would lose track of the score. In their most dismal season, 1969-70, they won only three matches out of 40. But nothing could dampen his &shyenthusiasm. Bromley were one of the last genuinely amateur teams left and fighting for survival in the lowest non-league &shydivision. And Dave was always on the &shysidelines cheering them on, no matter what.  He was Bromley’s most &shypassionate fan and – five decades later – he still is. Now 63, his dedication has been &shyrecognised on the big screen. It has not all been tears and despair. Dave told us: “This year is the first they’ve been fairly good and it’s disconcerting.” And in March he finally got a taste of what England fans felt in 66 when Bromley made it to Wembley. They reached the final of the FA Trophy – non-league teams’ equivalent of the FA Cup.  A dream had come true. Dave said: “It was the biggest Bromley game of my &shylifetime. I felt my whole life was unfolding a bit. But there's no happy ending.” Bromley’s opposition Brackley FC equalised in the final 20 seconds of the game, forcing a penalty shoot-out. True to their club heritage, Bromley lost. Dave said: “I was told after we missed the final penalty I sank to my knees &shyshouting, ‘Noooo.’ “And there may have been a tear. My wife Liz thought that was ridiculous.”  Dave’s unwavering love for his home team, nicknamed The Lillywhites, led to him write the book The Bromley Boys. It chronicles his endless trips to the team’s Hayes Lane ground and supporting the worst football team through their abysmal season of the late 1960s. In the film he is portrayed by Brenock, who was Olly in Game of Thrones. Martine and Alan Davies star as his parents. Its premiere to 1,100 people at Wembley was just four days after Bromley lost the final. Dave, who now lives in Menston, near Leeds, said: “It was bittersweet going back and I had to tell myself it was for a completely different thing that had nothing to do with our loss. “But the film seems to strike a chord with audiences. People do react with laughter and enjoyment.” At the age of 11 he listened to the World Cup final on a radio while travelling to Lund, Sweden, on a ferry.  His parents had refused to cancel the family holiday. He said: “I sulked all the way, getting more and more seasick as I listened to the match on a radio. I was so happy when they won I danced on this rocking ferry. I’m not sure anyone understood why. As a boy he begged his mum and dad to take him to football matches. His father Edward, who died in 2016 aged 96, occasionally took him to Fulham matches. Dave, whose mum is also dead, said: “I was &shyconvinced Dad loved &shyfootball as much as I did. “I only found out later he absolutely hated it. He was doing it so we could spend time together.” His parents wouldn’t let him go to watch a London team because he was too young.  But they allowed him to go to his local team Bromley – in Kent in the 60s but now a South London borough. Dave said of the team: “They were &shyabsolutely useless in those days. The first season I watched them was their worst season in history – they lost endlessly. But I got the bug.” He once ran away from boarding school to watch a meaningless evening game and had to walk nearly 20 miles back having spent the bus fare on tea. He said: “At 3.15am I was scared and hungry when a car pulled up. The driver opened the window and called my name. It was Dad. “He’d been driving round for hours &shytrying to find me. I got in the car and promptly burst into tears.” Another time, despite Bromley losing their last 13 games, Dave, then 14, hitched to a match because he was determined to see every fixture.  Afterwards Bromley’s star striker Alan Stonebridge , Dave’s hero, gave him a lift home. “I never wanted that journey to end,” said Dave, a dad-of-three. “My bedroom was covered in pictures of him.”   At 16, Dave spent &pound50 on a red three-wheeled car so he could offer other fans lifts to and from matches. But he recalled: “Within five minutes I had done a triple somersault in it after taking a corner too fast and had to go back to cadging lifts.” These are the anecdotes that &shyinspired The Bromley Boys book in 2006. He said the book is very niche and has been called “wilfully uncommercial” which made turning it into a film “even stranger”. He said: “But the story has heart and soul. It’s about flawed relatable people who have found their place in life. “There are lots of books about &shysupporting popular sides but what about the rubbish non-glory teams and the people who go and watch year-in year-out with absolutely no reward.” To this day, aside from some years living in New Zealand and the US, Dave never misses a game.

title: fun loving dad who never
story: News'Fun-loving dad who was never down' died months after being given cancer all clearColin Douglas, who died just weeks after being told his cancer had returned, was still making his family laugh right until the very end&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByHannah Robinson16:32, 23 JUN 2018Updated16:52, 23 JUN 2018NewsColin with his partner, Annette&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A heartbroken family have paid tribute to their absolute hero who died just months after being given the all-clear after a cancer battle.  Colin Douglas was diagnosed with esophageal cancer in October, but by April was declared cancer-free and he and his family were overjoyed. But on May 20 he was given devastating news: he had secondary cancer and it spread to his spine, lymph nodes and lesions. Weeks later, on June 11, he was dead.  Now his family have paid tribute to the fighter and say he made everybody laugh until the very end, the Hull Daily Mail reports.  Annette Shreeve, Colin’s partner of almost three years, said: “He was still making us laugh right until the very end, and he had a great relationship with the staff at Castle Hill.  “I knew him for almost three years but it wasn’t long enough.” Colin, of Bilton Grange, east Hull, was a driver for disabled children but his main loves in life were snooker, cars, fishing and, most importantly, his children. “His children were everything to him,” said Colin’s close friend Carl Gibson. “He was so proud of them and they meant the world to him. “He had several hobbies but I can’t stress to you how much he loved his snooker. I’ll never forget the time I asked him to take me and a friend to Skirlaugh and you could tell he really didn’t want to but he was having kittens, when we got in the car and he realised I had asked him to give Jimmy White a lift. “His life was snooker but he was also really into cars and fishing. He had planned to go sea fishing this year, and he was so excited. He had a fraternity with him no matter what his hobby was.” Colin’s love was so great for snooker he taught his son Josh to play, with a touching final picture of the pair showing them as runners up in a recent tournament. “He won so many trophies and he taught me how to play,” said Josh, 22. “He was so fun-loving and was never down. “His other love was drag racing and anything to do with cars. He would go on trips away with other car lovers.” Josh’s sister, 19-year-old Jordan Douglas, added: “He was very fun and brilliant, and could make games out of anything. You were never bored when you were around him.  “I called him Hulk because he was so strong and tall, he was 6ft and weighed nearly 19st. Everybody was really proud of him and loved him.” Colin’s younger sister, Jacqueline Douglas, said: “He was a pain in the backside when we were younger, just like any brother, but he was so protective and made me the person I am today. “I couldn’t have asked for a better big brother. He lived in the same house for 21 years, and the neighbours all grew to love him as well. “He was the perfect neighbour and would always help anyone out if they needed anything changing or looking at. They’re all just as shocked as us that he has died, and I think Colin was the only person who came to terms with what was going to happen. “He was so young and we all were certain he would get longer.”

title: how last victoria cross holder
story: NewsHow last Victoria Cross holder 'Big Bill' hurled rocks and beer cans to keep the North Korean army at bayBill Speakman died aged 90, 66 years after he fought off a sustained attack from 6,000 solders for more than four hours with a shrapnel wound in his leg&nbspShare&nbspCommentsByLaura Connor21:08, 22 JUN 2018Updated21:10, 22 JUN 2018NewsVictoria Cross holder Bill Speakman with his medals (Image: REX/Shutterstock)&nbspShare&nbspCommentsGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe only living Victoria Cross holder from the Korean War has died at the age of 90. War hero Bill Speakman was just 24 when he fought off a sustained attack from 6,000 Chinese and North Korean solders for more than four hours in 1951, despite receiving a shrapnel wound in his leg. The 6ft 6in soldier, known as ‘Big Bill’, pelted enemy soldiers with grenades until they ran out. He then hurled rocks, tins and even empty beer bottles at them. He was given a hero’s welcome by thousands of people on the streets of his hometown of Altrincham, Greater Manchester, when he returned a year later. Speakman became the first man to receive a Victoria Cross from Queen Elizabeth II for outstanding bravery, and was one of only a handful of living holders of the award.  Despite his great height and courage, he was known as a modest and quiet man who struggled to adjust to civilian life and the celebrity which followed his great investiture. Born on September 21, 1927, Bill was raised by a single mum and started his military career when he was 17, serving in Germany, Italy and Hong Kong with the Black Watch, 3rd Battalion, Royal Regiment of Scotland. He transferred to the King’s Own Scottish Borderers (KOSB) as a private when British troops mobilised for Korean service in 1950.  His regiment was bombarded with shell and mortar fire in the early hours of November 4, 1951 as they defended a position on Maryang San in Korea, but Speakman fought back with grenades and beer bottles sent to the line for consumption by the platoon, breaking up several enemy attacks. His charge against the enemy allowed his overrun troops enough time to evacuate their wounded. Talking of the life-or-death seige, he said: “It was hand-to-hand. There was no time to pull back the bolt of the rifle. “It was November, the ground was hard, so grenades bounced and did damage.”  Recalling the moment he was handed the award, he said: “When I got it The King [George VI] was alive but he was very ill. “He awarded me the VC and then he died. So The Queen – I was her first VC. It was a wonderful moment. I think she was nervous and I was very nervous.” The announcement of the Victoria Cross award said: “Private Speakman’s heroism under intense fire throughout the operation and when painfully wounded was beyond praise and is deserving of supreme recognition.”

title: identical twins parents thought autism
story: NewsIdentical twin's parents thought he had autism or anxiety - but it turned out to be something far deadlierSid Earley was diagnosed with a brain tumour after doctors initially dismissed his symptoms - but now the seven-year-old is being supported by his identical twin brother Mac&nbspShareByNathan Standley15:15, 23 JUN 2018NewsSid with his brother Mac while in hospital&nbspShareGet daily updates directly to your inbox+ SubscribeThank you for subscribing!Could not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email An identical twin whose symptoms were shrugged off as anxiety or autism was later told he has a brain tumour.  Sid Earley began missing school due to headaches and bouts of vomiting, but doctors said his symptoms were nothing to worry about. But the seven-year-old's concerned parents, Alex and Simon, noticed his eyes started to turn inwards and flicker, and he developed coordination issues, so they took him to the optician.  It was then, on June 5, that Sid was sent for an MRI scan, and his parents were told he had a huge tumour on his brain, reports the Liverpool Echo.  Sid’s aunt Robyn Dunbar, 33, said his parents were devastated and have been “living in a bubble” ever since the diagnosis.  She added: “They’re just completely in it at the moment, it’s so hard. They want to get in touch with people who have been in similar situations, people who might know about it and maybe help point them in the right direction. The couple, from Prenton, Wirral had to sit and wait as their little boy underwent 10 hours of invasive brain surgery to remove the tumour, which had been pressurising his facial nerves, causing sight and coordination difficulties. Although the surgery was successful, the aggressive nature of the tumour and the microscopic cancer cells remaining in his brain meant there was no option but to send him abroad for potentially life-saving proton therapy treatment, which is not available on the NHS.  So Robyn set up a JustGiving page to raise funds to help pay for the treatment and support Sid and his family. In under one week, over &pound10,000 has been raised. Robyn said: “We just want to say a massive thank you to everyone that’s helped us, we don’t think we can say thank you enough.” The money will also go towards helping Sid’s twin brother Mac travel with his brother to support him during his treatment. Mrs Dunbar said Mac had been hit particularly hard by Sid’s illness. She said: “They’re like peas in a pod, they couldn’t be closer. They absolutely adore each other. “Mac spent every night in Sid’s bed while his brother was in hospital. ‘Super Sid’, as he has become known on his aunt’s JustGiving page, has since been discharged from hospital and will be treated as an outpatient while he waits for his treatment to become available.
